awd_titl_txt: REU Site: Socially Relevant Computing and Analytics
awd_abstract_narration:
This "Socially Relevant Computing and Analytics" Research Experiences for Undergraduates Site (SRCA-REU) will immerse a diverse group of undergraduates in a vibrant research community of faculty and graduate students working on cutting-edge interactive and intelligent media, improving learning and healthcare outcomes, educational technologies, and diverse forms of interaction with and through computers. “Socially relevant computing” is a term used in a broad sense to include systems and data that have social relevance. Students will be recruited from underrepresented groups and colleges and universities with limited research opportunities through the STARS Computing Corps, an NSF-funded national consortium of institutions dedicated to broadening participation in computing. The project's focus on relevant cutting-edge technologies is a proven focus that can improve retention for minorities and women.

Students in SRCA-REU will participate in a variety of research projects that range from interactive systems/games (addressing theme such as humans in learning, health, creativity, and providing food and shelter) to machine learning/analytics research (that deals with data generated from people interacting in these systems as well as the need for ethics in machine learning/analytics of such data). These research activities can potentially lead to the discovery and evaluation of innovative, interactive solutions to open problems in serious games, data analytics, intelligent tutoring, narrative generation, and biological algorithms. The SRCA-REU will provide explicit research mentoring training to faculty and graduate student mentors, and explicitly encourage faculty and student publication of results. SRCA-REU students will present their work at an undergraduate research competition and will be encouraged to submit their technical papers as peer reviewed publications. Using the Affinity Research Groups and STARS Training for REUs models, faculty and graduate student mentors will be engaged with undergraduates to create a supportive culture of collaboration while promoting individual contributions to research through just-in-time training for both mentors and students throughout the summer.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

pgm_ref.pgm_ref_txt: REU SITE-Res Exp for Ugrd Site

por.por_cntn:
From 2020-2024, the Socially Relevant Computing and Analytics (SRCA) REU Site program, led by PI Tiffany Barnes, has hosted 61 research experiences for undergraduates at North Carolina State University. Due to our targeted recruitment and selection processes, our overall Site implementation has attracted more non-male and underrepresented minorities participants than is nationally recognized in Computer Science (Taulbee Report 2019). Women and transgender students represented 60% of our 50 nsf-funded participants, and students identifying as Black/Hispanic/Multiracial have represented 18% (9/50) of our participants. Our SRCA REU Site has also demonstrated a strong commitment to providing research opportunities for students that may not otherwise have access; 24% of our participants are from non-doctoral institutions, and 54% were freshman/sophomores.

 The SRCA REU immersed a diverse group of undergraduates in a vibrant research community working on cutting-edge research including serious games and game analytics; computer science educational technologies and analytics, LLMs for education, and machine learning for education, bioinformatics, computing for good, and culturally sustaining curriculum research. The SRCA REU designed and implemented a tiered Mentor Training model to create a supportive culture. The tiered mentoring approach is valued by the REU students and is also effective in providing faculty and graduate student mentors with the opportunity to develop their mentoring and research project management skills. In addition to our faculty and graduate mentoring structure, in most summers REU participants, in turn, mentored diverse high school interns participating in our summer programs.  This experience contributes to the opportunities our REU students have to build their scientific leadership and research skills.Each year, REU students presented their work at an undergraduate research symposium and were encouraged to submit their technical papers as peer reviewed publications.
